elements.content: Ten new coordination complexes, [Cd3(H2L)­(H2O)7]­·6H2O (1), [Mn3(H2L)­(H2O)7]­·7H2O (2), [Zn3(H2L)­(H2O)6]­·6H2O (3), [Co3(H2L)­(H2O)6]­·5.75H2O (4), [Fe3(H2L)­(H2O)8]­·6.5H2O (5), [Co3(H2L)­(teta)3]­·5H2O (6), [Ni4(L)­(teta)4]­·2.5H2O (7), [Ni3(H2L)­(teta)­(H2O)6]­·6H2O (8), [Cd4(L)­(teta)4­(H2O)2]­·H2O (9), and [Cu2(H4L)­(teta)2]­·2H2O (10) (H8L = 1,4,8,11-tetrazacyclododecane-N,N′,N″,N‴-tetra-methylene-isophthalic acid and teta = 5,5,7,12,12,14-hexamethyl-1,4,8,11-tetraazacyclotetradecane) have been synthesized. Their structures have been confirmed and further characterized by relative physical methods. Compounds 1 and 2 are isomorphous and demonstrate the identical three-dimensional (3D) (4,6)-connected nets with (64·72)­(68·76·8) topologies. Compounds 3–5 are isostructural and unfold 3D 4-fold interpenetrating frameworks with (412·63) topologies. Compound 6 is a 3D 2-fold interpenetrating framework with (412·63) topology. Compound 7 features a 3D 6-connected (412·63) net. Compounds 8 and 9 reveal two-dimensional (2D) layers, where hydrogen-bonding interactions further link adjacent layers together to obtain 3D supramolecular architectures. Compound 10 presents a one-dimensional ribbon. These ribbons are combined by π–π stackings to produce a 2D supramolecular layer. In addition, the fluorescent properties of H8L and compounds 1, 3, and 9 have been explored, and the luminescent sensing properties of compounds 1 and 3 for small molecules have been studied.

elements.content: Ten coordination polymers constructed by a novel azamacrocyclic octacarboxylate ligand 1,4,8,11-tetrazacyclododecane-N,N′,N″,N‴-tetra-methylene-isophthalic acid and transition metal ions were successfully synthesized and structurally characterized. The fluorescent properties of certain compounds were investigated at room temperature.

The fluorescent properties of certain compounds were investigated at room temperature.

elements.content: Azamacrocycles modified by additional substituents stand for a kind of flexible ligand, and their glamorous properties provide them extensive applications for activation of small molecules, ion recognition, and capture abilities. For this reason, many efforts have been devoted to devising and preparing azamacrocycles and their metal complexes. In most cases, one metal ion might be centrally located, and part of its coordination sites could be occupied by nitrogen atoms of the azamacrocyclic ligand. The introduction of pendant substituents to the azamacrocycles could significantly expand the coordination diversities of the azamacrocyclic ligands because these substituents could also be involved in the coordination with metal centers. Among the substituted arms, carboxylic acids are particularly attractive because of their multiple binding sites and versatile coordination modes. The carboxylate arms can also enhance the cation-binding abilities and selectivities as compared with their parent azamacrocyclic ligands. Up to now, some metal complexes based on one, two, or three pendant substituents have been reported. However, the studies on the basis of four-armed ligating units are considerably scarce.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Azamacrocycles modified by additional substituents stand for a kind of flexible ligand, and their glamorous properties provide them extensive applications for activation of small molecules, ion recognition, and capture abilities. For this reason, many efforts have been devoted to devising and preparing azamacrocycles and their metal complexes. In most cases, one metal ion might be centrally located, and part of its coordination sites could be occupied by nitrogen atoms of the azamacrocyclic ligand. The introduction of pendant substituents to the azamacrocycles could significantly expand the coordination diversities of the azamacrocyclic ligands because these substituents could also be involved in the coordination with metal centers. Among the substituted arms, carboxylic acids are particularly attractive because of their multiple binding sites and versatile coordination modes. The carboxylate arms can also enhance the cation-binding abilities and selectivities as compared with their parent azamacrocyclic ligands. Up to now, some metal complexes based on one, two, or three pendant substituents have been reported. However, the studies on the basis of four-armed ligating units are considerably scarce.

elements.content: Taking inspiration from the above viewpoints, we synthesized an unprecedented octacarboxylate-based azamacrocyclic ligand 1,4,8,11-tetrazacyclododecane-N,N′,N″,N‴-tetra-methylene-isophthalic acid (H8L) (Scheme ). The ligand with eight carboxylate groups can furnish multiple coordination patterns with metal ions. Also, the flexible nature of so many −CH2– linkers will be conducive to the adjustment of the ligand conformations.
elements.clean_text: Taking inspiration from the above viewpoints, we synthesized an unprecedented octacarboxylate-based azamacrocyclic ligand 1,4,8,11-tetrazacyclododecane-N,N',N",N‴-tetra-methylene-isophthalic acid (H8L) (Scheme ). The ligand with eight carboxylate groups can furnish multiple coordination patterns with metal ions. Also, the flexible nature of so many -CH2- linkers will be conducive to the adjustment of the ligand conformations.

elements.content: In this paper, 10 metal-azamacrocyclic complexes have been synthesized, namely, [Cd3(H2L)­(H2O)7]­·6H2O (1), [Mn3(H2L)­(H2O)7]­·7H2O (2), [Zn3(H2L)­(H2O)6]­·6H2O (3), [Co3(H2L)­(H2O)6]­·5.75H2O (4), [Fe3(H2L)­(H2O)8]­·6.5H2O (5), [Co3(H2L)­(teta)3]·5H2O (6), [Ni4(L)­(teta)4]­·2.5H2O (7), [Ni3(H2L)­(teta)­(H2O)6]­·6H2O (8), [Cd4(L)­(teta)4­(H2O)2]­·H2O (9), and [Cu2(H4L)­(teta)2]­·2H2O (10). The macrocyclic neutral ligand 5,5,7,12,12,14-hexamethyl-1,4,8,11-tetraazacyclotetradecane (teta) has been used because of its excellent coordination abilities with metal ions. Their structures were measured and identified by physical methods. The effects of the coordination pattern of H8L, the teta ligand, and pH values on the resultant structures are discussed.

The macrocyclic neutral ligand 5,5,7,12,12,14-hexamethyl-1,4,8,11-tetraazacyclotetradecane (teta) has been used because of its excellent coordination abilities with metal ions. Their structures were measured and identified by physical methods. The effects of the coordination pattern of H8L, the teta ligand, and pH values on the resultant structures are discussed.

elements.content: Compounds 1 and 2 (Figure S1a in the ) are isostructural, and hence, only the structure of 1 is discussed here. In 1, Cd1 and Cd2 display distinctively distorted pentagonal bipyramid coordination spheres (Figure a). Cd1 is encircled by two (H2L)6– anions and three water molecules, while Cd2 is environed by three (H2L)6– anions and two water molecules. Cd1 and (H2L)6– anion locate in inversion centers. Each (H2L)6– anion attaches to eight Cd­(II) ions, with four methylene-isophthalate arms displaying two kinds of coordination patterns (mode I, Scheme ). Each of four arms of (H2L)6– anion coordinates to two Cd­(II) ions, in which the arm labeled as O1–O4 and its symmetry-related one adopt μ2-η1:η1:η1:η1 coordination patterns, while the arm labeled as O5–O8 displays a partially deprotonated μ2-η1:η2:η0:η0 pattern. By this means, (H2L)6– anions unite Cd­(II) ions to produce an intricate three-dimensional (3D) framework (Figure b). In this framework, there are binuclear units, each of which is constructed by two Cd2 ions and two μ2-O5 atoms ().
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structures of [Cd3(H2L)(H2O)7]⋅6H2O (1) and [Mn3(H2L)(H2O)7]⋅7H2O (2)

Compounds 1 and 2 (Figure S1a in the ) are isostructural, and hence, only the structure of 1 is discussed here. In 1, Cd1 and Cd2 display distinctively distorted pentagonal bipyramid coordination spheres (Figure a). Cd1 is encircled by two (H2L)6- anions and three water molecules, while Cd2 is environed by three (H2L)6- anions and two water molecules. Cd1 and (H2L)6- anion locate in inversion centers. Each (H2L)6- anion attaches to eight Cd(II) ions, with four methylene-isophthalate arms displaying two kinds of coordination patterns (mode I, Scheme ). Each of four arms of (H2L)6- anion coordinates to two Cd(II) ions, in which the arm labeled as O1-O4 and its symmetry-related one adopt μ2-η1:η1:η1:η1 coordination patterns, while the arm labeled as O5-O8 displays a partially deprotonated μ2-η1:η2:η0:η0 pattern. By this means, (H2L)6- anions unite Cd(II) ions to produce an intricate three-dimensional (3D) framework (Figure b). In this framework, there are binuclear units, each of which is constructed by two Cd2 ions and two μ2-O5 atoms ().

elements.content: Compounds 3–5 show similar 4-fold interpenetrated 3D frameworks (). Therefore, only the description of 3 is given as a representation. As seen in Figure a, Zn1 and Zn2 take on highly distorted octahedral geometries. Each Zn­(II) ion is encircled by two (H2L)6– anions and two water molecules. Each (H2L)6– anion joins with six Zn­(II) ions, with the -methylene-isophthalate arm labeled as O1–O4 displaying a partially deprotonated μ1-η0:η0:η1:η1 coordination pattern, and the arm labeled as O5–O8 adopting a μ2-η1:η1:η1:η1 pattern (mode II, Scheme ). By this means, (H2L)6– anions integrate Zn­(II) ions to bring out a 3D framework (Figure b).

elements.content: When teta was introduced in the reaction, a 2-fold interpenetrated 3D framework of 6 was obtained. The asymmetric unit contains three six-coordinated half Co­(II) ions, three half teta, half (H2L)6– anion, and two and a half free water molecules. As shown in Figure a, each of the three Co­(II) ions is completed by two (H2L)6– anions and one teta ligand. Each of the three teta ligands acts as a tetradentate ligand and chelates to one Co­(II) ion with its four N atoms, respectively. Each (H2L)6– anion links six Co­(II) ions, with the arm labeled as O1–O4 displaying a partially deprotonated μ1-η1:η0:η0:η0 pattern, and the arm labeled as O5–O8 adopting a μ2-η1:η0:η1:η0 pattern (mode III, Scheme ). By this way, (H2L)6– anions interact with Co­(II) ions to create a 3D framework (Figure b).

Structure of [Co3(H2L)(teta)3]⋅5H2O (6)

When teta was introduced in the reaction, a 2-fold interpenetrated 3D framework of 6 was obtained. The asymmetric unit contains three six-coordinated half Co(II) ions, three half teta, half (H2L)6- anion, and two and a half free water molecules. As shown in Figure a, each of the three Co(II) ions is completed by two (H2L)6- anions and one teta ligand. Each of the three teta ligands acts as a tetradentate ligand and chelates to one Co(II) ion with its four N atoms, respectively. Each (H2L)6- anion links six Co(II) ions, with the arm labeled as O1-O4 displaying a partially deprotonated μ1-η1:η0:η0:η0 pattern, and the arm labeled as O5-O8 adopting a μ2-η1:η0:η1:η0 pattern (mode III, Scheme ). By this way, (H2L)6- anions interact with Co(II) ions to create a 3D framework (Figure b).

elements.content: As shown in Figure a, Ni1, Ni2, and Ni3 present analogous octahedral coordination configurations. Each of the three Ni­(II) ions is ligated by two L8– anions and one teta ligand. The L8– anion attaches to eight Ni­(II) ions, with each of four -methylene-isophthalate arms adopting a μ2-η1:η0:η1:η0 coordination pattern (mode IV, Scheme ). By this means, L8– anions connect Ni­(II) ions to yield a 3D framework (Figure b).

elements.content: In the structure, each L8– anion links to another six individual L8– anions through eight Ni­(II) ions (). Topologically, L8– anions can be considered as 6-connectors, and Ni­(II) ions can be regarded as linkers. As a consequence, the overall motif of 7 can be simplified as a 3D skeleton with the short Schläfli symbol of (412·63) (Figure c).

elements.content: In 8, three kinds of Ni­(II) cations lie at inversion centers and exhibit two different coordination geometries. Ni1 and Ni3 ions locate in six-coordinated octahedral centers, in which Ni1 is surrounded by four (H2L)6– anions and two water molecules, while Ni3 is surrounded by two (H2L)6– anions and four water molecules. Ni2 lies at an almost perfect square-planar geometry and is environed by one teta ligand (Figure a). Each (H2L)6– anion serves as a tetradentate ligand with its -methylene-isophthalate arm labeled as O1–O4 in a μ2-η1:η0:η1:η0 pattern and the arm labeled as O5–O8 in a partially deprotonated μ1-η0:η0:η0:η1 pattern (mode V, Scheme ). In this manner, Ni­(II) ions are linked by (H2L)6– anions to construct a layer (Figure b). Interestingly, channels exist with approximately 17.803(4) × 14.634(5) Å2 dimensions, and the channels are occupied by Ni­(teta)2+ cations.

Ni2 lies at an almost perfect square-planar geometry and is environed by one teta ligand (Figure a). Each (H2L)6- anion serves as a tetradentate ligand with its -methylene-isophthalate arm labeled as O1-O4 in a μ2-η1:η0:η1:η0 pattern and the arm labeled as O5-O8 in a partially deprotonated μ1-η0:η0:η0:η1 pattern (mode V, Scheme ). In this manner, Ni(II) ions are linked by (H2L)6- anions to construct a layer (Figure b). Interestingly, channels exist with approximately 17.803(4) × 14.634(5) Å2 dimensions, and the channels are occupied by Ni(teta)2+ cations.

Structure of [Cd<sub>4</sub>(L)­(teta)<sub>4</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>]·H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>9</bold>)

In Figure a, two independent Cd­(II) ions locate in two types of six-coordinated octahedral centers. Cd1 center is furnished by one L8– anion, one teta ligand, and one water molecule. Cd2 center is surrounded by two individual L8– anions and one teta ligand. The L8– anion is completely deprotonated and serves as a sexadentate ligand, with -methylene-isophthalate arm labeled as O1–O4 exhibiting a μ2-η1:η0:η1:η0 coordination pattern, and the arm labeled as O5–O8 is in a μ1-η1:η0:η0:η0 pattern (mode VI, Scheme ). L8– anions unite Cd2 atoms to attain a thick layer, with Cd1 atoms arranging at intervals above and below the layer (Figure b).
elements.clean_text:
In addition, an intermolecular hydrogen-bonding interaction (O6-H6A⋅⋅⋅O3W#7, ) further links the layer to form a 3D supramolecular architecture (Figure c).

Structure of [Cd4(L)(teta)4(H2O)2]⋅H2O (9)

In Figure a, two independent Cd(II) ions locate in two types of six-coordinated octahedral centers. Cd1 center is furnished by one L8- anion, one teta ligand, and one water molecule. Cd2 center is surrounded by two individual L8- anions and one teta ligand. The L8- anion is completely deprotonated and serves as a sexadentate ligand, with -methylene-isophthalate arm labeled as O1-O4 exhibiting a μ2-η1:η0:η1:η0 coordination pattern, and the arm labeled as O5-O8 is in a μ1-η1:η0:η0:η0 pattern (mode VI, Scheme ). L8- anions unite Cd2 atoms to attain a thick layer, with Cd1 atoms arranging at intervals above and below the layer (Figure b).

elements.content: Compound 10 has a ribbon structure. The Cu­(II) ion is in a six-coordinated octahedral style and is surrounded by two (H4L)4– anions and one teta ligand (Figure a). Each (H4L)4– anion links four Cu­(II) cations with four -methylene-isophthalate arms adopting partially deprotonated μ1-η1:η0:η0:η0 coordination patterns simultaneously (mode VII, Scheme ). In this way, (H4L)4– anions connect Cu­(II) ions to yield an infinite ribbon, with the teta ligands sticking on both rims of the ribbonlike wheels (Figure b). There exist π–π stackings between the benzene rings of (H4L)4– anions of neighboring chains (with the interplane and intercenter lengths of 3.41 and 3.67 Å, respectively), which connect the chains into a supramolecular layer (Figure c).

Structure of [Cu2(H4L)(teta)2]⋅2H2O (10)

Compound 10 has a ribbon structure. The Cu(II) ion is in a six-coordinated octahedral style and is surrounded by two (H4L)4- anions and one teta ligand (Figure a). Each (H4L)4- anion links four Cu(II) cations with four -methylene-isophthalate arms adopting partially deprotonated μ1-η1:η0:η0:η0 coordination patterns simultaneously (mode VII, Scheme ). In this way, (H4L)4- anions connect Cu(II) ions to yield an infinite ribbon, with the teta ligands sticking on both rims of the ribbonlike wheels (Figure b). There exist π-π stackings between the benzene rings of (H4L)4- anions of neighboring chains (with the interplane and intercenter lengths of 3.41 and 3.67 Å, respectively), which connect the chains into a supramolecular layer (Figure c).

elements.content: As in the descriptions above, H8L ligands coordinate to metal centers just using pendant carboxylate groups, whereas the nitrogen atoms on the ring are free of coordination. It is not common that the metal ion does not enter the internal cavity of the tetraaza core but leaves empty coordination sites. In this work, the H8L ligand can be partly or fully deprotonated. Also, the ligand can adopt various coordination modes because of its multiple carboxylate groups. As shown in Scheme , the (H4L)4–, (H2L)6–, or L8– anions in compounds 1–10 can connect to eight, six, or four metals. Different coordination numbers of the anions have significant influences on the resultant structures. In compounds 1, 2, and 7, each (H2L)6– or L8– anion coordinates with eight metal ions (modes I and IV), resulting in 3D frameworks, respectively. In compounds 3–6 and 9, each (H2L)6– or L8– anion links six metal ions (modes II, III, and VI), leading to 3D frameworks of 3–6 and 2D layer of 9. The structural distinctions between 9 and 3–6 can be interpreted by the steric hindrance of the teta ligand in 9. When fewer number of connections in (H2L)6– or (H4L)4– anions appeared in the structures (connecting to 4- metal ions in modes V and VII), lower dimensional motifs (2D frameworks of 8 and 10) were formed.

Coordination Patterns of the H8L Ligand

As in the descriptions above, H8L ligands coordinate to metal centers just using pendant carboxylate groups, whereas the nitrogen atoms on the ring are free of coordination. It is not common that the metal ion does not enter the internal cavity of the tetraaza core but leaves empty coordination sites. In this work, the H8L ligand can be partly or fully deprotonated. Also, the ligand can adopt various coordination modes because of its multiple carboxylate groups. As shown in Scheme , the (H4L)4-, (H2L)6-, or L8- anions in compounds 1-10 can connect to eight, six, or four metals. Different coordination numbers of the anions have significant influences on the resultant structures. In compounds 1, 2, and 7, each (H2L)6- or L8- anion coordinates with eight metal ions (modes I and IV), resulting in 3D frameworks, respectively. In compounds 3-6 and 9, each (H2L)6- or L8- anion links six metal ions (modes II, III, and VI), leading to 3D frameworks of 3-6 and 2D layer of 9. The structural distinctions between 9 and 3-6 can be interpreted by the steric hindrance of the teta ligand in 9. When fewer number of connections in (H2L)6- or (H4L)4- anions appeared in the structures (connecting to 4- metal ions in modes V and VII), lower dimensional motifs (2D frameworks of 8 and 10) were formed.

The neutral macrocyclic ligand teta also plays a vital role in the resultant structures. Taking compounds [Cd3(H2L)­(H2O)7]­·6H2O (1) and [Cd4(L)­(teta)4­(H2O)2]·H2O (9) for example, compound 1 features a 3D framework. However, when teta was introduced into the system, a layer structure of 9 was obtained. The reason is that teta acts as a tetradentate chelating ligand in 9, which prevents the formation of a higher dimensional framework. The structure differences between [Co3(H2L)­(H2O)6]­·5.75H2O (4) and [Co3(H2L)­(teta)3]­·5H2O (6) can also be assigned to the teta. Although both compounds display 3D frameworks with (412·63) topologies, compound 4 shows a 4-fold interpenetrating framework, while 6 only displays a 2-fold interpenetrating framework due to the steric effect of teta.

Effects of teta

The neutral macrocyclic ligand teta also plays a vital role in the resultant structures. Taking compounds [Cd3(H2L)(H2O)7]⋅6H2O (1) and [Cd4(L)(teta)4(H2O)2]⋅H2O (9) for example, compound 1 features a 3D framework. However, when teta was introduced into the system, a layer structure of 9 was obtained. The reason is that teta acts as a tetradentate chelating ligand in 9, which prevents the formation of a higher dimensional framework. The structure differences between [Co3(H2L)(H2O)6]⋅5.75H2O (4) and [Co3(H2L)(teta)3]⋅5H2O (6) can also be assigned to the teta. Although both compounds display 3D frameworks with (412⋅63) topologies, compound 4 shows a 4-fold interpenetrating framework, while 6 only displays a 2-fold interpenetrating framework due to the steric effect of teta.

elements.content: The structural differences between 7 and 8 are due to the pH values of the reaction mixtures. The final mixture pH values were approximately 7.4 and 5.4 in 7 and 8, respectively. As a result, the carboxylic groups in these two compounds display fully and partially deprotonated patterns. This leads to the different coordination modes of L8– and (H2L)6– anions. Finally, compound 7 exhibits a 3D framework, while 8 shows a lower dimensional layer. The phenomenon that a lower pH value leads to partially deprotonated carboxylate can also be found in previous reports.

The phenomenon that a lower pH value leads to partially deprotonated carboxylate can also be found in previous reports.

elements.content: Coordination polymers based on Zn­(II) and Cd­(II) ions have attracted wide interest because of their potential application in chemical optical sensors and electroluminescent devices. The solid-state excitation and emission spectra of Na6(H2L), Na8L as well as compounds 1, 3, and 9 were measured at ambient temperature (Figure ). The decay curves of compounds 1, 3, and 9 are described in . The photoluminescent spectra of Na6(H2L) and Na8L show emission maxima at 481 nm (λex = 380 nm) and 486 nm (λex = 380 nm), respectively. In general, this kind of fluorescence originates from π* → n or π* → π transitions.
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescent Properties

Coordination polymers based on Zn(II) and Cd(II) ions have attracted wide interest because of their potential application in chemical optical sensors and electroluminescent devices. The solid-state excitation and emission spectra of Na6(H2L), Na8L as well as compounds 1, 3, and 9 were measured at ambient temperature (Figure ). The decay curves of compounds 1, 3, and 9 are described in . The photoluminescent spectra of Na6(H2L) and Na8L show emission maxima at 481 nm (λex = 380 nm) and 486 nm (λex = 380 nm), respectively. In general, this kind of fluorescence originates from π* → n or π* → π transitions.

elements.content: Irradiated by UV light, the compounds show emission bands centered at 452 nm (λex = 380 nm) for 1, 495 nm (λex = 380 nm) for 3, and 466 nm (λex = 380 nm) for 9. These emissions can be assigned to the luminescence of (H2L)6– or L8– anions due to their resemblance to Na6(H2L) or Na8L. Compared with free Na6(H2L) or Na8L, the emission bands of compounds 1 and 9 exhibit blue shifts, which probably results from the metal coordination interactions to the corresponding anions. However, for compound 3, a red shift occurs in the emission spectra with a value of 14 nm compared to free Na6(H2L). This may be ascribed to the fact that their coordination to Zn­(II) ions decreases the π* → n energy gap.

elements.content: The luminescence decay curves of compounds 1, 3, and 9 fit well into double-exponential functions, respectively. The results indicate that there are two luminescence centers in each compound. The emission decay lifetimes are τ1 = 1.52 ns (63.70%) and τ2 = 5.47 ns (36.30%) (χ2 = 1.006) for 1, τ1 = 2.13 ns (57.08%) and τ2 = 7.15 ns (42.92%) (χ 2 = 1.006) for 3, τ1 = 2.35 ns (63.98%) and τ2 = 7.61 ns (36.02%) (χ 2 = 1.009) for 9, respectively. These luminescence lifetimes are much shorter than those steming from a triplet state (>10–3 s). Obviously, the emission of light is induced by the shift of energy states with the same spin multiplicity.

elements.content: Recently, a wide range of luminescent coordination polymers for the sensing of cations, anions, small molecules, vapors, and biomolecules have been reported. In this work, we select compounds 1 and 3 as representative of Cd­(II)- and Zn­(II)-containing compounds to explore the potential sensing of small solvent molecules. The stable 1-solvent and 3-solvent suspensions were prepared on the basis of previous literature. The solvents involved are CHCl3, CH2Cl2, CCl4, THF, MeOH, CH3CN, nitrobenzene, toluene, ethylbenzene, o-xylene, m-xylene, p-xylene, and mesitylene. As displayed in Figure and , the emission intensities of 1 and 3 in diverse solvent suspensions take on different degrees of quenching effects because they are heavily reliant on the solvent molecules. The quenching effects may be ascribed to the interactions of the solvents with some sites of the compound, which can affect the energy transfer process. Particularly, the emission intensities of nitrobenzene suspensions show serious quenching effects. In the nitrobenzene suspensions, the nitrobenzene molecules can be closely adsorbed on the surface of dispersed corresponding samples. The quenching effect on the luminescence intensity can be attributed to the electron transfer from the electron-donating framework of 1 or 3 to the highly electron-withdrawing nitro group of nitrobenzene. Such solvent-dependent quenching behavior is attractive and meaningful for selective sensing of nitrobenzene molecules.

elements.content: The UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy of H8L ligand and compounds 1–10 was carried out in the solid state at room temperature (Figure ). The ligand exhibits two strong absorption bands centered at 245 and 290 nm, which can be ascribed to π* → n or π* → π transitions. Compounds 1–10 exhibit similar broad bands from 200 to 350 nm in the ultraviolet region, which are dominated by the absorption of H8L ligands. Compounds 4–8 and 10 take on additional bands with maxima at 550, 457, 524, 534, 664, and 531 nm in the visible region, respectively. These absorption bands are tentatively attributed to the d–d transitions of metal ions as reported.

elements.content:
To examine the thermal stability of compounds 1–10, TGA was performed (). Refer to the for detailed description.

Magnetic Properties

The magnetic properties of compounds 2, 5, 7, and 8 were measured from polycrystalline samples (Figure ).

For 2, the χm T value at 300 K is 3.61 cm3 mol–1 K, which is lower than the expected value (4.37 cm3 mol–1 K) for one Mn­(II) center with S = 5/2 (Figure a). For the χm T value, there is a smooth decrease from 300 to 46 K and a more pronounced decline from 46 to 2 K (with the ultimately value of 0.99 cm3 mol–1 K). This feature is characteristic of the occurrence of an antiferromagnetic coupling between the Mn­(II) ions. The magnetic susceptibility in the range of 46–300 K obeys the Curie–Weiss Law with the Curie constant, C = 4.05 cm3 mol–1 K, and the Weiss constant, Θ = −47.89 K. The negative Θ value further confirms the presence of antiferromagnetic interaction in 2.

Upon cooling, the values of χm T keep smoothly decreasing in 300–28 K range and then exhibit a maximum value of 1.11 cm3 mol–1 K at 20 K before going down quickly to a minimum value of 0.33 cm3 mol–1 K at 2 K. This behavior is indicative of antiferromagnetic coupling between the Ni­(II) centers. The magnetic susceptibility above 24 K can be well fit to the Curie–Weiss Law with C = 1.28 cm3 mol–1 K and Θ = −8.46 K.

elements.content: In brief, 10 new coordination polymers have been successfully prepared by reaction of the functionalized octacarboxylic acids azamacrocyclic ligand H8L, the neutral ligand teta, together with transition metal salts. These compounds take on fascinating 1D, 2D, and 3D structures. The results indicate that polycarboxylate-substituted azamacrocycles can be good candidates for the construction of coordination polymers with fascinating motifs. The empty coordination sites in the tetraazacycle ligands give us new inspiration to explore the specific reasons, such as adjusting the number of the substituted carboxylic arms and introducing small alkaline earth metals into the cavity, in our following work. The luminescent properties of 1 and 3 in different solvent suspensions show that they could be used to detect nitrobenzene through noticeable fluorescence quenching. It is expected that other related coordination polymers with luminescent-sensing properties could be obtained in the future.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In brief, 10 new coordination polymers have been successfully prepared by reaction of the functionalized octacarboxylic acids azamacrocyclic ligand H8L, the neutral ligand teta, together with transition metal salts. These compounds take on fascinating 1D, 2D, and 3D structures. The results indicate that polycarboxylate-substituted azamacrocycles can be good candidates for the construction of coordination polymers with fascinating motifs. The empty coordination sites in the tetraazacycle ligands give us new inspiration to explore the specific reasons, such as adjusting the number of the substituted carboxylic arms and introducing small alkaline earth metals into the cavity, in our following work. The luminescent properties of 1 and 3 in different solvent suspensions show that they could be used to detect nitrobenzene through noticeable fluorescence quenching. It is expected that other related coordination polymers with luminescent-sensing properties could be obtained in the future.

In the structure, each L8– anion links to another six individual L8– anions through eight Ni­(II) ions (). Topologically, L8– anions can be considered as 6-connectors, and Ni­(II) ions can be regarded as linkers. As a consequence, the overall motif of 7 can be simplified as a 3D skeleton with the short Schläfli symbol of (412·63) (Figure c).

Photoluminescent Properties

Coordination polymers based on Zn­(II) and Cd­(II) ions have attracted wide interest because of their potential application in chemical optical sensors and electroluminescent devices. The solid-state excitation and emission spectra of Na6(H2L), Na8L as well as compounds 1, 3, and 9 were measured at ambient temperature (Figure ). The decay curves of compounds 1, 3, and 9 are described in . The photoluminescent spectra of Na6(H2L) and Na8L show emission maxima at 481 nm (λex = 380 nm) and 486 nm (λex = 380 nm), respectively. In general, this kind of fluorescence originates from π* → n or π* → π transitions.

For 7, the χm T value at 300 K is 1.33 cm3 mol–1 K, which corresponds to an isolated Ni­(II) ion (S = 1/2, g = 2). Upon cooling, the values of χm T keep smoothly decreasing in 300–28 K range and then exhibit a maximum value of 1.11 cm3 mol–1 K at 20 K before going down quickly to a minimum value of 0.33 cm3 mol–1 K at 2 K. This behavior is indicative of antiferromagnetic coupling between the Ni­(II) centers. The magnetic susceptibility above 24 K can be well fit to the Curie–Weiss Law with C = 1.28 cm3 mol–1 K and Θ = −8.46 K.

For 8, χm T is almost constant from 300 to 45 K and then increases as the temperature is lowered and reaches a maximum value of 1.74 cm3 mol–1 K at 14 K. Finally, it decreases to 1.02 cm3 mol–1 K at 2 K, which shows that there may be both weak ferromagnetic interactions and single-ion zero-field-splitting of isolated Ni­(II) ions. The magnetic susceptibility above 24 K can be well fit to the Curie–Weiss Law with C = 1.16 cm3 mol–1 K, and Θ = 0.92 K.
